title: 112_s3490
content: The Act may be cited as the "Stop Abuse, Violence, and Exploitation of Elders Act of 2012" or the "SAVE Elders Act of 2012". The population of individuals age 65 or older in the United States is growing and is estimated to reach 1/5 of the total population by 2030. A 2011 report found that 1 out of every 7 older individuals experienced elder abuse, and 54 percent of crimes against victims age 65 or older go unreported. The Crime Victims Fund supports victims of crime through forfeited bonds and fines. The Crime Victims Fund does not receive taxpayer funds and does not allocate specific amounts to individuals aged 65 or older who experience abuse. Elder abuse investigations are expected to increase by 28 percent by 2020. Definitions of elder abuse vary between the Federal Government and State governments. The primary definition for consistent administration of elder abuse programs by the State. Amendments to the Victims of Crime Act of 1984. Amendment to the Crime Victims Fund under the Victims of Crime Act of 1984 allows for the availability of $20,000,000 for grants under section 1404F in fiscal years with increased obligation limitations. The Crime Victims Fund amendment allows for grants under section 1404F with an amount less than $20,000,000 to be deposited into an elder abuse reserve fund for future grants. The Director has the authority to carry over amounts in the elder abuse fund. The Director has the authority to carry over amounts in the elder abuse reserve fund from fiscal year to fiscal year. Amounts in the fund are not subject to the obligation limitation. The total amount available for grants under section 1404F in a fiscal year is capped at $20,000,000. The Victims of Crime Act of 1984 is amended to adjust the obligation limitation based on the available amount in the Fund. Technical and conforming amendments are made to various sections within the Act. The Victims of Crime Act of 1984 is amended to adjust obligation limitations in various sections by changing references from (d)(2) to (d)(1) and (d)(4) in subsections (g) and section 1404. Congress expresses its sense regarding these changes. In amending the Victims of Crime Act of 1984, Congress expresses the need to increase the maximum amount available for obligation in the Fund established under section 1402 for compensation and assistance to victims of elder abuse. The Victims of Crime Act of 1984 is amended to provide compensation and assistance to victims of elder abuse. "Compensation and assistance to victims of elder abuse are provided under SEC. 1404F." In SEC. 1404F, elder abuse is defined as abuse, exploitation, or neglect of individuals aged 65 or older who are lawfully present in the United States. This definition also includes any other conduct defined as elder abuse under state laws for states receiving grants under this section. The Director shall use allocated amounts to make grants to States for crime victim assistance programs supporting victims of elder abuse and programs improving the investigation and prosecution of elder abuse cases. The Director shall apportion percentages of allocated amounts to various States and territories, including the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, the United States Virgin Islands, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands. Amounts remaining after allocation will be used for other purposes. The Director will apportion remaining amounts among States based on a formula considering the population of individuals aged 65 or older in each State compared to all States. The Federal share of the cost of a program carried out by a State using a grant under this section may not exceed 80 percent. The Attorney General shall submit a biennial report to Congress on the use of funds and the administration of this section. The Attorney General must provide a detailed analysis of how states distribute funds received under this section and identify any significant problems. Recommendations for legislative remedies must also be included.
